module.title: the ‚Äì definite article ü•à
module.p: There are four basic forms of the definite article in Gaelic ‚Äì
These forms agree with the gender/number and case of the following noun ‚Äì
The precise pronunciation (and written representation) of each form of the Gaelic definite article depends on the initial sound of the following word ‚Äì

ul.li:
leniting an ‚Äì
If the following word begins with p-, c-, b-, g-, m-, the word is lenited and the form of the article changes to a‚Äô.
If the following word begins with f-, the word is lenited.
If the following word begins with s- followed by a vowel, -l-, -r- or -n-, it is prefixed by t-.

non-leniting an ‚Äì
If the following word begins with a labial consonant (i.e. p-, b-, f-, m-), the form of the article changes to am.
If the following word begins with a vowel, it is prefixed by t-.

na ‚Äì
If the following word begins with a vowel, it is prefixed by h-.

nan ‚Äì
If the following word begins with a labial consonant (i.e. p-, b-, f-, m-), the form of the article changes to nam.

module.p: Here are example paradigms for all combinations of gender, part-of-speech and initial sound ‚Äì

ul.li: masculine nouns ‚Äì ainm, balach, blaigeard, broc, ceann, cladh, cnoc, cr√πn, duine, dl√πth, dream, eilean, fear, fl√πr, freumh, gille, glutaire, gnog, gr√®im, ionad, loch, mac, naomh, √≤ran, peann, ploc, prionnsa, r√†mh, sabhal, sg√†than, sgl√®atair, sgread, sloc, spiorad, spleadh, spreadhadh, sruth, stoc, structair, taigh, tlus, tn√π, traon, ubhal
feminine nouns ‚Äì abhainn, buthaid, bliadhna, br√†iste, caileag, clach, cn√≤, croit, deoch, dl√≤th, drochaid, eaglais, fairge, fleasg, fras, geug, gl√πn, gn√πis, greis, iuchair, l√†mh, s√πil,
ordinals ‚Äì d√†rna, treas, ceathramh, c√≤igeamh, siathamh, seachdamh, ochdamh, naoidheamh, deicheamh, aonamh, ficheadamh, lethcheudamh, ceudamh, m√¨leamh
new ordinals ‚Äì tritheadamh, ceathradamh, caogadamh, seasgadamh, seachdadamh, ochadamh, naochadamh
cardinals ‚Äì aon, d√†, tr√¨, ceithir, c√≤ig, sia, seachd, ochd, naoi, deich
adjectives ‚Äì deagh, droch, seann, dearbh, f√¨or, s√†r

module.p: However, there are some notable exceptions to these rules regarding definite article agreement in modern Gaelic ‚Äì

ol.li: When followed by the ordinal numeral ciad first, the nominative singular definite article is always a‚Äô, even when it specifies a masculine noun, e.g. th√†inig a‚Äô chiad fhear a-steach the first man came in
The ordinal modifier ath next is no longer preceded by t- when the specified noun is masculine nominative singular, e.g. th√†inig an ath fhear a-steach the next man came in

box.title: definite article + ainm
box.p: ainm name is a masculine noun starting with the vowel a(i)-

box.title: definite article + balach
box.p: balach boy is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b-

box.title: definite article + blaigeard
box.p: blaigeard scoundrel is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b(l)-

box.title: definite article + broc
box.p: broc badger is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant b(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceann
box.p: ceann head is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + cladh
box.p: cladh cemetery is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c(l)-

box.title: definite article + cnoc
box.p: cnoc hill is a masculine noun starting with the velar consonant c(n)-

box.title: definite article + duine

box.title: definite article + dl√πth
box.p: dl√πth warp is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant d(l)-

box.title: definite article + dream
box.p: dream tribe is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant d(r)-

box.title: definite article + eilean

box.p: fl√πr flower is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant f(l)-

box.title: definite article + ionad
box.p: ionad centre is a masculine noun starting with the vowel i(o)-

box.title: definite article + loch

box.title: definite article + mac

box.title: definite article + prionnsa
box.p: prionnsa prince is a masculine noun starting with the labial consonant p(r)-

box.title: definite article + r√†mh
box.p: r√†mh oar is a masculine noun starting with the dental consonant r-

box.title: definite article + sabhal
box.p: sabhal barn is a masculine noun starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + sg√†than
box.p: sg√†than mirror is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg-

box.title: definite article + sgl√®atair
box.p: sgl√®atair slater is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg(l)-

box.p: sgread screech is a masculine noun starting with the hard sybillant sg(r)-

box.p: gl√πn knee is a feminine noun starting with the velar consonant g(l)-.

box.title: definite article + iuchair
box.p: iuchair key is a feminine noun starting with the vowel i(u)-.

box.title: definite article + d√†rna
box.p: d√†rna second is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + treas
box.p: treas third is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant t(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceathramh
box.p: ceathramh fourth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + c√≤igeamh
box.p: c√≤igeamh fifth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + siathamh
box.p: siathamh sixth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + seachdamh
box.p: seachdamh seventh is an ordinal numeral, starting with the soft sybillant s-

box.title: definite article + ochdamh
box.p: ochdamh eighth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the vowel o-

box.title: definite article + naoidheamh
box.p: naoidheamh ninth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant n-

box.title: definite article + deicheamh
box.p: deicheamh tenth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + aonamh
box.p: aonamh first is an ordinal numeral, starting with the vowel a(o)-

box.title: definite article + ficheadamh
box.p: ficheadamh twentieth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the labial consonant f-

box.title: definite article + lethcheudamh
box.p: lethcheudamh fiftieth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the dental consonant l-

box.title: definite article + ceudamh
box.p: ceudamh hundredth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + m√¨leamh
box.p: m√¨leamh thousandth is an ordinal numeral, starting with the labial consonant m-

box.title: definite article + aon
box.p: aon one, same is a cardinal numeral starting wth the vowel a(o)-

box.title: definite article + d√†
box.p: d√† two is a cardinal numeral starting with the dental consonant d-

box.title: definite article + tr√¨
box.p: tr√¨ three is a cardinal numeral starting with the dental consonant t(r)-

box.title: definite article + ceithir
box.p: ceithir four is a cardinal numeral starting with the velar consonant c-

box.title: definite article + ciad
box.p: ciad first is an ordinal numeral. It occurs with the definite article as follows ‚Äì
Note that nowadays the masculine nominative singular form is generally a‚Äô chiad ‚Äì
The traditional nominative masculine form an ciad / ceud is assumed to be an archaism ‚Äì
In some progressive dialects / registers, a‚Äô chiad can replace na ciad in the genitive feminine singular or in the plural ‚Äì

box.title: definite article + ath
box.p: ath next is an ordinal modifier.
Archaic: an t-ath fhear
Progressive: (ainm) an ath t√® ???
Plural examples?
